questions.text: Two weeks after admission to the intensive care unit for a hemorrhagic stroke, a 54-year-old man regains consciousness. At the time of admission, a CT scan of the head showed evidence of intraparenchymal hemorrhage from a ruptured aneurysm. The patient is mechanically ventilated via a tracheostomy tube. Neurologic examination shows quadriplegia, exaggerated deep tendon reflexes, and a Babinski sign in both legs. He responds to questions by blinking, but neck, lingual, and other facial movements are lost. Doll's eye testing shows restricted horizontal movement and preserved vertical movement. On mental status examination, he is alert and comprehends the physician's questions. This patient's condition is most likely caused by bleeding in a region supplied by which of the following arteries?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The posterior cerebral artery (PCA) is a paired artery that contributes to the posterior cerebral circulation. This artery supplies the occipital lobe, ventral midbrain, thalamus, and inferomedial temporal lobe. Ruptured PCA aneurysms commonly manifest with unilateral findings including contralateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing (due to infarction of the visual cortex in the occipital lobe), contralateral paresis (due to infarction of the corticospinal tract in the midbrain), and contralateral sensory loss (due to infarction of the ventral posterolateral nucleus or the ascending sensory tracts). If damage occurs to the dominant (most commonly left) hemisphere, patients present with alexia without agraphia, anomic aphasia, and visual agnosia. If damage occurs to the nondominant (most commonly right) hemisphere, patients present with prosopagnosia. A PCA hemorrhage is unlikely to explain this patient's bilateral symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

The anterior communicating artery (ACom) is a single artery that provides the anastomosis between left and right anterior cerebral circulation. This artery gives rise to small and large branches (e.g., median artery of the corpus callosum and subcallosal artery) that supply the anterior columns of the fornix, cingulate gyrus, hypothalamus, lamina terminalis, optic chiasm, and paraolfactory area. The junction between the ACom and one of the paired anterior cerebral arteries (ACAs) is the most common site of cerebral saccular aneurysms, which can manifest with bitemporal hemianopia (due to compression of the optic chiasm). Aneurysm rupture causes findings characteristic of infarction of the arterial territory of the ACA, including contralateral paralysis and sensory deficits more prominent in the lower than the upper extremity (due to infarction of the motor and sensory cortices of the lower extremity) and urinary incontinence. An ACom hemorrhage is unlikely to explain this patient's bilateral symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

The posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) is a paired artery that contributes to the posterior cerebral circulation. The PICA supplies the lateral part of the medulla and the inferior part of the cerebellum. PICA aneurysm rupture causes lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome), which manifests with hoarseness, hiccups, decreased gag reflex (due to infarction of the nucleus ambiguus), vertigo, nystagmus, and vomiting (due to infarction of cranial nerve VIII nuclei). Unilateral findings include ipsilateral Horner syndrome (due to infarction of the descending sympathetic nervous system), ipsilateral ataxia and dysmetria (due to infarction of the inferior cerebellar peduncle), ipsilateral decreased pain and temperature sensation in the face (due to infarction of the spinal nucleus and descending tract of cranial nerve V), and contralateral decreased pain and temperature sensation in the body (due to infarction of the lateral medullary spinothalamic tract). PICA hemorrhage is unlikely to explain this patient's bilateral symptoms.

D) INCORRECT:

The middle cerebral artery (MCA) is a paired artery that contributes to the anterior cerebral circulation. This artery supplies a large part of the lateral cortex (including the lateral portion of the frontal and parietal lobes, temporal lobe, frontal lobe, putamen, globus pallidus, and parts of the internal capsule and caudate nucleus). MCA aneurysm rupture causes contralateral paralysis and sensory deficits more prominent in the face and upper extremity (due to infarction of the motor and sensory cortices of the upper body parts). If damage occurs in the dominant (most commonly left) hemisphere, patients present with aphasia. If damage occurs in the nondominant (most commonly right) hemisphere, patients present with hemineglect. An MCA hemorrhage is unlikely to explain this patient's bilateral symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

The anterior spinal artery (ASA) is a single artery that contributes to the posterior cerebral circulation. This artery supplies the anterior two-thirds of the spinal cord and the lower medulla at the midline. Bleeding from an aneurysm of the ASA can cause bilateral medial medullary syndrome with quadriplegia (due to bilateral infarction of the corticospinal tract), loss of proprioception (due to bilateral infarction of the medial lemniscus), and anarthria (due to bilateral infarction of the nucleus of cranial nerve XII in the lower medulla). However, ASA hemorrhage would not explain this patient's bulbar palsy, paralysis of the face and neck muscles, or loss of horizontal eye movements.

F) CORRECT:

The basilar artery is located on the ventral surface of the pons and contributes to the posterior cerebral circulation. A ruptured basilar artery aneurysm can cause locked-in syndrome by causing bilateral damage to the midbrain, which contains cranial nerve III (CN III) and CN IV nuclei, pons (containing CN V, VI, VII, and VIII nuclei), medulla (containing CN IX, X, XI, and XII nuclei), and corticobulbar and corticospinal tracts. Peripheral motor symptoms (e.g., quadriplegia, exaggerated deep tendon reflexes, and positive Babinski signs in both legs) are caused by bilateral interruption of the corticospinal tracts. Bulbar palsy and paralysis of the face and neck muscles are caused by bilateral interruption of the corticobulbar tracts and damage to the motoric cranial nerve nuclei of CN V, VII, IX, X, XI, and XII. Horizontal gaze palsy is caused by damage to ocular cranial nerve nuclei (CN VI) and associated visual paths in the paramedian pontine reticular formation. Despite the extensive injury, many vital functions persist due to collateral blood supply to the midbrain tectum (preserved blinking and vertical eye movement), reticular activating system (preserved consciousness), cerebral cortex (preserved language comprehension and cognition), and spinothalamic tracts coursing through the dorsal pons (preserved sensation). See “Clinical features of stroke by affected vessel” table.

Management of locked-in syndrome includes physiotherapy, which consists of passive stretching exercises and frequent repositioning to avoid decubitus ulcers. Patients learn to communicate using blinking, vertical eye movements, eye-gaze sensor-controlled computer communication programs, and speech synthesizers. Some patients may recover some motor control, breathing, swallowing, and/or speaking ability.
Image Description:

Caudal view

The circle of Willis is formed around the pituitary stalk by the following paired arteries:
- Anterior cerebral arteries (terminal branches of the internal carotids)
- Internal carotid arteries (proximal to the origin of the middle cerebral arteries)
- Posterior cerebral arteries (terminal branches of the vertebral arteries)

The anterior communicating artery (ventral to the optic chiasm) connects the anterior cerebral arteries.

The posterior communicating artery (a branch of internal carotid artery; lies on the lateral aspect of the pituitary stalk) connects the internal carotid artery and the posterior cerebral artery.

The basilar artery, formed by the fusion of the two vertebral arteries, lies in the midline groove of the dorsal aspect of the pons. Pontine and labyrinthine branches arise from the basilar artery.

The anterior spinal artery, formed by the fusion of the branches of the vertebral artery, lies in the anterior median fissure of the spinal cord.
questions.hint: This patient presents after a period of coma with quadriplegia and anarthria in conjunction with the preservation of consciousness, cognition, vertical eye movements, and blinking, all of which are characteristic of locked-in syndrome. This condition is typically a result of bilateral damage to the ventral pons.

questions.text: Two weeks after admission to the intensive care unit for a hemorrhagic stroke, a 54-year-old man regains consciousness. At the time of admission, a CT scan of the head showed intraparenchymal hemorrhage due to a ruptured aneurysm. He is currently mechanically ventilated via a tracheostomy tube. On neurologic examination, you find quadriplegia, exaggerated deep tendon reflexes, and a Babinski sign in both legs. He responds to questions by blinking, but neck, lingual, and other facial movements are absent. Doll's eye testing reveals restricted horizontal eye movement with preserved vertical movement. On mental status examination, he is alert and comprehends your questions. This patient's condition is most likely caused by bleeding in a region supplied by which one of the following arteries?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The basilar artery is located on the ventral surface of the pons and contributes to the posterior cerebral circulation. A ruptured basilar artery aneurysm can cause locked-in syndrome by causing bilateral damage to the midbrain, which contains cranial nerve III (CN III) and CN IV nuclei, pons (containing CN V, VI, VII, and VIII nuclei), medulla (containing CN IX, X, XI, and XII nuclei), and corticobulbar and corticospinal tracts. Peripheral motor symptoms (e.g., quadriplegia, exaggerated deep tendon reflexes, and positive Babinski signs in both legs) are caused by bilateral interruption of the corticospinal tracts. Bulbar palsy and paralysis of the face and neck muscles are caused by bilateral interruption of the corticobulbar tracts and damage to the motoric cranial nerve nuclei of CN V, VII, IX, X, XI, and XII. Horizontal gaze palsy is caused by damage to ocular cranial nerve nuclei (CN VI) and associated visual paths in the paramedian pontine reticular formation. Despite the extensive injury, many vital functions persist due to collateral blood supply to the midbrain tectum (preserved blinking and vertical eye movement), reticular activating system (preserved consciousness), cerebral cortex (preserved language comprehension and cognition), and spinothalamic tracts coursing through the dorsal pons (preserved sensation). See “Clinical features of stroke by affected vessel” table.

Management of locked-in syndrome includes physiotherapy, which consists of passive stretching exercises and frequent repositioning to avoid decubitus ulcers. Patients learn to communicate using blinking, vertical eye movements, eye-gaze sensor-controlled computer communication programs, and speech synthesizers. Some patients may recover some motor control, breathing, swallowing, and/or speaking ability.

Key learning point: Locked-in syndrome is most often caused by basilar artery infarction or hemorrhage affecting the ventral pons, resulting in quadriplegia and preserved consciousness with only vertical eye movements and blinking spared.

Caudal view

The circle of Willis is formed around the pituitary stalk by the following paired arteries:
- Anterior cerebral arteries (terminal branches of the internal carotids)
- Internal carotid arteries (proximal to the origin of the middle cerebral arteries)

The basilar artery, formed by the fusion of the two vertebral arteries, lies in the midline groove of the dorsal aspect of the pons. Pontine and labyrinthine branches arise from the basilar artery.

The anterior spinal artery, formed by the fusion of the branches of the vertebral artery, lies in the anterior median fissure of the spinal cord.

The posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) is a paired artery that contributes to the posterior cerebral circulation. The PICA supplies the lateral part of the medulla and the inferior part of the cerebellum. PICA aneurysm rupture causes lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome), which manifests with hoarseness, hiccups, decreased gag reflex (due to infarction of the nucleus ambiguus), vertigo, nystagmus, and vomiting (due to infarction of cranial nerve VIII nuclei). PICA hemorrhage is unlikely to explain this patient's bilateral symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

The middle cerebral artery (MCA) is a paired artery that contributes to the anterior cerebral circulation. This artery supplies a large part of the lateral cortex (including the lateral portion of the frontal and parietal lobes, temporal lobe, frontal lobe, putamen, globus pallidus, and parts of the internal capsule and caudate nucleus). MCA aneurysm rupture causes contralateral paralysis and sensory deficits more prominent in the face and upper extremity (due to infarction of the motor and sensory cortices of the upper body parts). D) INCORRECT:

The posterior cerebral artery (PCA) is a paired artery that contributes to the posterior cerebral circulation. This artery supplies the occipital lobe, ventral midbrain, thalamus, and inferomedial temporal lobe. Ruptured PCA aneurysms commonly manifest with unilateral findings including contralateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing (due to infarction of the visual cortex in the occipital lobe), contralateral paresis (due to infarction of the corticospinal tract in the midbrain), and contralateral sensory loss (due to infarction of the ventral posterolateral nucleus or the ascending sensory tracts). If damage occurs to the dominant (most commonly left) hemisphere, patients present with alexia without agraphia, anomic aphasia, and visual agnosia. If damage occurs to the nondominant (most commonly right) hemisphere, patients present with prosopagnosia. A PCA hemorrhage is unlikely to explain this patient's bilateral symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

The anterior communicating artery (ACom) is a single artery that provides the anastomosis between left and right anterior cerebral circulation. This artery gives rise to small and large branches (e.g., median artery of the corpus callosum and subcallosal artery) that supply the anterior columns of the fornix, cingulate gyrus, hypothalamus, lamina terminalis, optic chiasm, and paraolfactory area.
